lesson.title: Quick Guide to Using Android Studio and the Emulator
lesson.summary: Familiarize yourself with this IDE for a smoother and more efficient app development experience.

concepts.title: Quick Guide to Using Android Studio and the Emulator

atoms.text:
# Tour Intro

In order to be an effective Android developer, you’ll need to be familiar with the tool that you’ll be using more than 90% of the development time - Android Studio!

You’re not alone if the first time you opened Android Studio and recoiled from the aftershock after seeing *all* the features.

atoms.caption: Android Studio is a powerful IDE with lots of features to help you as a developer.

atoms.text:
The sheer number of buttons, settings, and configurations in Android Studio can definitely cause option paralysis, stopping you from even starting. 

Don’t fret. In this lesson we will go over the main components of the IDE (Integrated Development Environment):
- The Tool Windows
- Android Studio Shortcuts
- Android Studio Updates and Understanding Release Notes
- Image Compression 

And before you know it you’ll be an old pro at finding your way around this helpful tool.

# The Tool Windows

In addition to the main window pane where you add your code, Android Studio has a number of Tool Windows to task specific purposes - Project, Gradle, Terminal, etc. 

### Accessing (4 Options) 

**Option 1:** The Tool Windows are the side panes in the left, right, and bottom edges of the main window:

atoms.caption: The Tool Windows are the side panes in the left, right, and bottom edges of the main window in Android Studio.

atoms.text: **Option 2:** Tool Windows are also accessible from the top toolbar window of Android Studio via  *View > Tool Windows*:
**Option 3:** Click on the **Quick Access Menu** in the bottom left corner of Android Studio (small grey square). Hovering over the icon pulls up a list of available Tool Window options.
**Option 4:** Lastly, in the main window, buttons with a number indicate the tool window can be opened by pressing *ALT (COMMAND for Macs) + The Corresponding Number (Ex: 1:Project)*

### Using a Tool Window

Once a tool window is open, you can access its specific Settings from the cog icon in the top right corner:

atoms.caption: Access Settings from this icon once a tool window is open

atoms.text: Next to it is the the Hide icon which slides the window closed:

atoms.caption: Hide icon to slide the window closed

atoms.text: Here’s a list of commonly used tool windows. For the scope of this program, we’ll only focus on the ones marked with a *.

|**Tool Window**|**Description**| | |------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | Android Monitor* | Provides access to the Android debugging system - monitoring log output from a running application, taking screenshots and videos of the application, stopping a process and performing basic debugging task| | Gradle* | Shows the Gradle tasks that help the project build and run correctly. Don’t worry if you’re not familiar with Gradle for now; we will cover Gradle in more detail later in the course. In short, Gradle is the underlying system that helps wrap up Android projects and make sure they run properly. | | Project* | Shows all the files in the project. Double-clicking on a file opens it up to be edited. | | Terminal* | Provides direct access to a Command-Line interface of the computer that Android Studio is running on. For Windows, it uses the Command Prompt Interface. For Macs and Linux, it uses the Terminal.

The Command-Line Interface is the most direct ways to type commands to the computer.

[Quick Guide to Command Line](https://www.davidbaumgold.com/tutorials/command-line/)
|TODO |When developing, developers can make note of tasks that need to be completed by typing a TODO comment directly in the source file.

Android Studio will pattern match the TODO pattern and list all the TODOs in a project in this Tool Window to be reviewed and completed in the future.

[Click for example TODO Image](http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/RiPqwGyqyfwfIlnszq4l86pdds-PIi9UzyM2EsNu6dCZwqqsnPuxrBA43t1DWrneWDw6DVPeNkt3DgGhdfqv=s0#w=842&h=302)| |Captures | Captures a bug report from the connected device which contains device logs, stack traces, and other diagnostic information to help you find and fix bugs in your app. ([Click for info to Enable](https://developer.android.com/studio/debug/am-screenshot.html)) | | Event Log | Displays messages relating to events and activities performed within Android Studio. For example, it shows if a project was built successfully or if an application is running. | | Favorites | A variety of project items can be added to the Favorites list.

To add a file to Favorites , in the *Project View > Right Click on the File > Add to Favorites*

[Click for screenshot](http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/WSlfA6fJOjYZ2XF5vaIF6Q335uqPqQvv7Kls6uGIL3CcvUr4PXBSjBrI0icI5mMuz62uLOeaVQ2v5-jkPdA=s0#w=382&h=282)

To add a method to Favorites, in the *Structure Tool Window > Right Click on the Method > Add to Favorites*

[Click for screenshot](http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/gVdRo8TiF68KGjOq71MJWzjrP-3x4nX2Xw8kyPJWPm_wrDQeRjcS3fPwmxHInVxXB1kc195-vH9EmOi1p4g=s0#w=532&h=226) | | Gradle Console | Displays information about what’s happening with the Gradle system (the underlying system that helps wrap up Android projects and make sure they run properly). The Gradle Console displays if there were any errors, warnings, or if it all ran successfully. | | Messages | Records output from the Gradle build system which can be used to help troubleshoot any problems when trying to compile the application. | | Structure | Shows high level view of the structure of whichever source file currently displayed in the editor. It includes information such as classes, methods and variables in the file. Selecting an item from the structure list will take you to that location in the source file in the editor window. |

Sourced from:
 http://www.techotopia.com/index.php/A_Tour_of_the_Android_Studio_User_Interface

|**Action**|**Explanation**| |---|---| |Cmd+Shift + A (Ctrl + Shift + A Windows or Linux PC)|Search through all of Android Studio

(In my opinion, the most important shortcut!)| |Code > Reformat Code|To ensure correct indentation and the right order of attributes| |Connect device (Emulator or Physical) > Android Monitor > Screen Capture|Obtain a screenshot from the device ([Additional Info](https://developer.android.com/studio/debug/am-screenshot.html)) |Android Monitor > Screen Record|Android Monitor lets you record an MP4 video from your hardware device for a maximum of three minutes. You can use the video for your marketing materials as well as for debugging, for example ([Additional Info](https://developer.android.com/studio/debug/am-video.html))| |View > Enter Presentation Mode|Presentation Mode - Useful when presenting something something from the IDE to a group so everyone can see it.

It will increases the font size and hides the toolbars. |Shift+Cmd+V |Instead of pulling up just the most recent copy-paste (Cmd+V) Android Studio remembers all your copy-pastes in the Clipboard Buffer.

concepts.title: Android Studio Updates and Understanding Release Notes

atoms.text:
## Version Updates

Google is constantly working on improving the IDE, adding improvements and fixing bugs. Periodic updates are pushed to Android Studio without requiring you to update your Android project. To manually check for updates, in the top toolbar of Android Studio go to  *Help > Check for Updates* (On Mac *Android Studio > Check for Updates*)

atoms.caption: Manually check for Android Studio updates via Android Studio > Check for Updates

atoms.text:
## Release Notes
Whether on your computer or mobile device, you’ve likely encountered the incessant prompt that “It’s time to update your software version!”

atoms.caption: Example image of a software update dialogue window that informs the user of the changes and allows them to install the updates.

atoms.text:
Once you’ve agreed to go through with the update, you’ll be presented several prompts confirming you agree to accept the changes in the latest version. 

These changes often come in the *Release Notes* which are the documents shared with the users of the software about what changes were made in the release. There is no standard way to format Release Notes, but most of them contain generally the same information (more details found [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Release_notes)). 

Android Studio publishes its Release Notes on its Developer Site [here](https://developer.android.com/studio/releases/index.html). 
There you can see what New features were added, what Changes were made, and Bug Fixes.

question.prompt: Which of these is NOT a Change in Android Studio v2.3.0 (March 2017)? [Source](https://developer.android.com/studio/releases/index.html#2-2-0)

answers.text: Instant Run is supported only when deploying your app to a target device running Android 5.0 (API level 21) or higher.
All templates now use `ConstraintLayout` as the default layout.
Android Emulator added a new feature: LTE option to the *Cellular > Network* type control.
There is now a separate button to push changes with Instant Run. After deploying your app, you now click *Apply Changes* to quickly push incremental changes to your running app using Instant Run.

atoms.text:
## Limited Device Memory

If you’ve ever bought a mobile device, you’ve likely encountered the question of how much memory to get. Devices, especially mobile devices, have a limited amount of memory which dictates how many applications run at a given time.

Image files can eat up a large chunk of the available memory. If your device runs out of memory, it can lead to nasty things happening such as your app crashing because there’s not enough for processes to run.

## Drawable Resources that Use Bitmaps

How do we balance the need to load images on our devices with the limited memory available?

Let’s review and discuss how images are displayed on the screen. 

We saw that we can set the source of an ImageView to be a  Drawable Resource (Ex: @drawable/cake)

atoms.caption: Earlier, we saw that we can set the source of an ImageView to be a  Drawable Resource (Ex: @drawable/cake).

atoms.text:
A Drawable resource can be generally described as any graphic that can be drawn on screen. 

Every Drawable is stored as individual files in one of the `res/drawable` folders. Drawable resources come in a [variety of different graphical file types](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/resources/drawable-resource.html) but a common one is called Bitmap. 

**Bitmaps** are graphic files that can have the extension `.png`, `.jpg`, or `.gif` and store images as a series of tiny squares called pixels.

atoms.caption: Bitmaps are stored as a series of small squares called Pixels. [Image Source](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Bitmap_vs_vector.svg)

atoms.text: Earlier, Katherine discussed with us the concept of *Density Independent Pixels*  ([Concept Video](https://classroom.udacity.com/courses/ud834/lessons/4027328704/concepts/42075886740923)) which allow ImageViews to scale and resize appropriately across a wide range screen sizes and pixel densities.

atoms.caption: Density Independent Pixels (dips) allow images to scale across different resolution devices.

atoms.text: Instead of using pixels, which vary in size and number across the different resolution devices, Android uses the unit *dips* so that the same bitmap of the image will appear the size no matter what device it’s displayed on.

atoms.caption: Android uses the unit dips so that the bitmaps size appears consistent across devices with different pixels.
Using dips (also dp), Android ensures an image appears the same across devices with different numbers of pixels on the screen.

atoms.text:
Now if you’re wondering if this means we’ll need different sized images for each resolution then you’re correct!

In order for that one 48dp x 48dp image to appear the same size across devices, we’ll need to have a number of images at different pixel size.

atoms.caption: We will need the same 48dp x 48 dp image in different pixel sizes.

atoms.text:
Having several resolutions (the pixel count) of bitmaps available in your project means that when the device is running the app, only the bitmap specific to the device will be loaded. So instead of uploading the original image which could be huge and excessive, the only version of the image loaded is the lower pixel-count version of the same image re-sized in order to fit the memory limits and screen size of a mobile device.

This means in our `res/` folder, the same image will have multiple dpi sizes. During run time when the image needs to be rendered, Android will determine which size is appropriate to pull up.

atoms.caption: The same image will need to be added at different dpi sizes

atoms.text:
# Generating Your Own Bitmaps

We just discussed the need to have several versions of a single image at different dpis - in order to have an image appear the same size we’ll need a number of different copies of the image at different resolutions (pixel count).


So in the projects you've worked on, we’ve provided you the images you've needed  at the various dpis, but you may be wondering how you'll get images in different densities for your own projects. 

Thankfully, there are a number of tools available to help you find free images as well as  generate images at different resolutions (if you have a friend who’s a UI designer, they can also be a helpful resource for getting images for your app :P)

Here's a compiled list with contributions from our helpful forum mentors (special shoutout to @sudhirkhanger and @Alex_234).

**First, Find Free Stock Images**
- [Pexels](https://www.pexels.com/)
- [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com/)
- [Creative Commons](https://search.creativecommons.org/)
- [Mashable list](http://mashable.com/2013/10/03/video-assets-creative-commons/#ROSbOEWDgiq3)
- [Sitepoint list](https://www.sitepoint.com/5-sites-fantastic-creative-commons-design-resources/)
- [Sitepoint list 2](https://www.sitepoint.com/30-creative-commons-sources/)

**Then, Use this Tool to Compress Images**
- [ImageMagick](https://www.imagemagick.org/script/index.php)

**Lastly, Convert Images to the Appropriate Resolution Sizes**
-  [Android Drawable Converter Tool](https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/7658-android-drawable-importer)
*(Important Note: A common thing students miss when using Android Drawable Converter Tool is setting the base resolution. When you have a drawable ready to give to the importer, you'll need to set it to the "source resolution".)*
